It was a long-standing TODO to have this in mathlib.

- ...

using the following format:

### PR summary [86f03a89e0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17957/commits/86f03a89e0353a90a69796736493c898bd82b8ae)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Combinatorics.Enumerative.InclusionExclusion`|619|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ inclusion_exclusion_card_biUnion`
`+ inclusion_exclusion_card_inf_compl`
`+ inclusion_exclusion_sum_biUnion`
`+ inclusion_exclusion_sum_inf_compl`
`+ prod_filter_not_mul_prod_filter`
`+ prod_indicator_biUnion_sub_indicator`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#17963~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#17964~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#17967~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Do we have a style guide about `negOnePow` vs `(-1 : Int) ^ _`? Here, you have a natural power and you don't need `Units Int`, so the latter would work.
I thought I would need to specify that `-1` is an `Int`, but apparently not anymore ðŸŽ‰
... as opposed to the version using `Finset.sum` which I have below
You can comment this out by adding *one single* `Int.` on line 60.
Well spotted. It used to be used all over the place for `negOnePow`

Can you perhaps mention a couple of these variants (at least the most relevant in your opinion), and describe in a few words what the inclusion-exclusion principle is in case someone knows it but is used to call it differently?

You could also add an ``## Implementation detail` section explaning the role played by decidability and `classical` showing up here and there.

> Can you perhaps mention a couple of these variants (at least the most relevant in your opinion), and describe in a few words what the inclusion-exclusion principle is in case someone knows it but is used to call it differently?

None seems particularly more relevant than the other ones, so I mentioned them all.

> You could also add an ``## Implementation detail`section explaning the role played by decidability and`classical` showing up here and there.

There are already many explanations of decidability (including a library note I believe), so I don't think it's my job to add anything here

I wonder if you cannot choose a different name for `f`. I agree it is a "choice function", but `f i` is a (fin)set, so why not calling it `S` or `T` or something like this? It would mark a more relevant difference from `g`.

Is having `inclusion_exclusion` in the declaration name really a Mathlib-style thing? I would have opted for something like `sum_biUnion_eq_alternating_sum`, or something like this. Of course, this remark applies to everything that follows.

I have argued in the past that the symbol-reading convention is suboptimal for named theorems because
1. There are a lot of symbols to mention
2. Variants of the same named theorem might have very different symbols, meaning that
  a. The name of one variant won't help you guess the name of the others
  b. The names make it hard to know how exactly the variants differ from each other

Here, it's easy to see at a glance that the four `theorem`s are variants of the same named theorem, and the names directly tell you whether it's talking about the `sum` or the `card`, and whether it's stated using `biUnion` or `Finset.inf _ fun _ â†¦ _á¶œ`
I don't know what to tell you besides the fact that `congr` and `congr!` are different tactics with different behaviors and syntax. `congr with t` doesn't introduce `ht : t âˆˆ s.powerset` in context

pullRequest.title: feat: inclusion-exclusion principle
